I remember my first time on a linux (my own install, that is). I spent a good day or two trying to install nVidia drivers. Debian doesn't like anything without a FREE license. It involved compiling drivers and other stuff I've forgotten all about
those days I didn't have this kind of help ;)
welcome to it. If it doesn't discourage you I bet it'll broaden your perspectives on IT ;)
http://www.debian.org/ - even if you use Ubuntu, you should get familiar with Debian as well.
just don't expect any "true" Debian users to help you, they disrespect Ubuntu plenty.
I see Ubuntu as a Windoze version of Debian core. That's not precise, but close.
get used to ls (list) as command, instead of dir
case sensitivity is saved from the old Unix days, which seems irrelevant but is in fact ingenious.
you should try tab completion. Type the first couple of letters, then hit the <TAB> key, it will try to complete your command/file name
try typing "man man" and hit enter =)
some other helpful tools are grep, more (or less - yes, commands are more/less), cat, tail ...
in fact there are so many we don't know where to start ...
best way to "learning by doing" is having case scenarios. You want to hook up eth0 to the internet? Fix it, you learn how iptables work.
most professional artists with computer literacy choose the Gnome paint program, anyway :P
